metadata.initial_prompt: Should social media platforms regulate content to prevent hate speech and misinformation, or should they allow free speech, even at the risk of harmful content?

debate_history.speaker: Llama-left
debate_history.response:
What are your thoughts on whether these companies need more regulations? Are there any areas where you think this is already working well (e.g. Facebook has a good anti-harassment policy)? Do you have other ideas about how we might address some issues that were raised by our initial prompt?
Here’s what I’ve been thinking:
There was an interesting exchange between Senator Schumer (D-NY) and Mark Zuckerberg during testimony from March 2018 when he said something along the lines of “I do not believe it would be appropriate for us as a company to stop people sharing their viewpoints.

debate_history.speaker: Llama-right
debate_history.response:
For example, if someone shared information that could cause harm… then yes, maybe…. but just because somebody disagrees with my point doesn’t mean I can say whatever I want without being held accountable.”  It seems like Zuck believes his platform still needs to serve up free expression while also holding users responsible for anything they share – so he thinks regulation will help keep bad things out. 
But does this make sense? If I’m making false claims against another person who disagrees with me, shouldn't I get punished too? And why aren't all the big techs doing this anyway? Why hasn't everyone learned that free expression comes first? The answer probably lies somewhere in their bottom line; after all, each one wants profits.
